3411F7809E2F4BEAACE4E3821C18DD05.description: Assess how mercantilism and the establishment of colonies in America led to increased global trading during the 17th and 18th centuries

CF0D839B1F394B15BF12C482F7850181.description: Describe how the uneven distribution of productive resources influenced historical events in the U.S.

88738D85854544DBB915EC7C163FA813.description: Describe the economic patterns of early settlements in North America and Oceania/Pacific islands

4D6071148B4845F1A492A1619E575970.description: Students apply concepts to explain how people organize for the production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services.

CDB1F1353BFE4FD9A16E03D3CD9CF6BD.description: Determine how various individuals and groups expanded opportunities for civic participation in the early history of the U.S. (e.g., abolitionists)

2D6E256BE4014A6FA76C8CB527CC58FD.description: Identify the three branches of the U.S. government, and explain how the checks and balances system works

56E9C8AB1A194BA9AAB642A49B617D87.description: Explain how colonial governments in the U.S.-affiliated Pacific (i.e., regions in the Pacific that are in political relationship with the U.S.) were based on key principles underlying American democracy, including social contract, majority rule, and equality of opportunity

75AE046CB17F45A888ED6F2E72ABC425.description: Students synthesize the sociocultural interactions among individuals, groups, and institutions to investigate structures of power and their impacts on authority and governance.

4D6FEC3B3EA74C3DA725D5DCA26FD34E.description: Apply concepts such as cohesion, diversity, and accommodation to local situations of conflict and cooperation

DC44FDBC1E664848B32B4BF7236FF003.description: Compare the views of indigenous peoples (Samoans, Native Americans) and non-indigenous peoples (Europeans and Americans) regarding the relationship between humans and the land

00929786A4E44B76B502B2F2D2C513E3.description: Students analyze how people create, learn, share, and adapt to culture.

24619FEA8DBC4685B879BD6FFA045F8B.description: Describe the geographic factors that influence patterns of settlement and the distribution of population in the U.S., past and present

08EF0BAC67444E1C90C7CF13297EB51C.description: Explain how colonization, westward expansion, immigration, and advances in transportation and communication changed geographic and demographic patterns in the U.S.

A05474D75089476B8BCB7046EE9BC09C.description: Students draw conclusions about changes in the relationship between people, places, and environments.

6673DA6C9B174E369866645AE4714CF4.description: Recognize the role and activities of government with regards to keeping track of changes to local geography and impacts on the environment

418520D8FF1F484A8626EBFB56C33923.description: Use geographic tools (e.g., historical maps, elevation, relief maps, and map scales) to further understand a significant event or issue in U.S. history

7A220F8310014D3D84BD87D9630AAE7D.description: Students research and report on where people and places are located and why, utilizing multiple geographic representations and tools (maps, globes, geospatial technologies).

1CB584B4954B444E9767B7E238F897BC.description: Hypothesize how people from different cultures develop different values and ways of interpreting experiences over time

2AB1F8E7BA744D7D9CD4D073C2012803.description: Draw conclusions about how culture changes in response to changing needs, concerns, social, political, and geographic conditions

D4C49599228B44278A743DAA0F5B176C.description: Students cite evidence that cultures are dynamic and change over time.

8DC626055853474A932B5976D03F4E68.description: Investigate reasons for emerging establishments in the colonies (e.g., conflicts among colonists, religious developments, and economic life in New England or Chesapeake or Southern colonies, American Samoa or other U.S.-affiliated regions)

3A85F05CC3AD4029BD4EF91F605942B1.description: Analyze political, religious, and economic aspects of European colonization of the U.S., and its affiliated states of the Pacific

E0ED38F7ADC04A24A58DE86F2863822F.description: Describe past communities in the context of the time period they existed without imposing present norms and values on historical events

DCECFCFBD1E74DE9ADD9C79F0254DFFC.description: Students investigate historical experiences of American Samoa, Oceania, the U.S., and the world to reveal patterns of continuity and change.

4ABBE41729424545BCA79E840FA24598.description: Analyze how the beliefs and education of the society in which a person resides shape his/her “point of view”

8294B99B39EF4A2EAC0C801DF542CF94.description: Explain how historical events might have turned out differently if specific individuals or groups had chosen different courses of action

4BC628DCCED2461B81AF9192D54A0515.description: Students reconstruct, interpret, and critique the causes and consequences of past events in the context of the institutions, values, and beliefs of the periods in which they took place.
